moves.4... cxd4 5. Bxd4 Ne7 6. Nc3 Nbc6 7. Bc5: This bishop move is always bad against the French because it will end up trading off White's good bishop.
moves.10... Bd7 11. Bxd7+ Qxd7 12. Nge2 Bc5 13: Not a lot to think about up to this point.
moves.14. a3 O-O 15. Nf4: Developing the black king rook is a good idea, but so is ...
moves.15... Nc4: In the actual game, White simply hung his queen by playing 16. Qd2.  Instead what follows is computer analysis of how the game should have continued, which I found instructive.
moves.16. b4: 16. Rb1, Ra2 and Qc1 leave white in about as bad of shape.  I will look at 16. Rb1 in another game.
moves.16... Be7: Black can do just as well with 16. ... Bb6 or 16. ... Ne3!
moves.25. Ne3: Now  25... Bxb4 26. axb4  completely does not work.
moves.26. Nxc3 Rc7xc3 27. Qd1: Computer analysis seems to want to take its time and not hurry.  It prefers moves like 27. ... h6 or Rc7, although Bg5 is also O.K.  Since I didn't really understand the other moves, I went with Bg5.
moves.27... Bg5: 27... Rxa3 Is clearly winning, but it allows just a touch of counterplay. 28. Rxa3 Qxa3 29. c4 Qxb4 30. cxd5 Rd8 is not quite as good.
moves.28. Qh5 Bxe3 29. fxe3 f5: Now if 30. g4 Rxa3 31. Rxa3 Qxa3 32. gxf5 Qxe3+ 33. Rf2 Qe1+ 34. Kg2 (34. Rf1 Qxb4 35. fxe6 Qb6+) 34... Qe4+ 35. Kg1 Rf8
moves.30... Rc8c4: This ends all counterplay.  31. g4 was a minor concern.
moves.40. Qb8: Black could play 40. ... h6 or 40. ... Re1, or ...
moves.40... Qe1:
Now if 41. Rh4 h6 42. Rd4 (42. Qf8+ Kg6 43. Rxh6+ Kxh6) 42... Re2 43. Rd3 Rxg2+ 44. Kxg2 Qe2+ 45. Kg1 Qxd3 46. Qxa7 $6 Qg3+ 47. Kf1 Qxh3+ 48. Kf2 Qh4+

Also 41. Qf8+ Is a mistake, although it takes some calculation to see that. Kg6 42. Qe8+ Kg5 43. Rf3 Rxf3 44. gxf3 Kf4 45. Qh5 (45. Qb8+ Kxf3 Forcing mate.) 45... Qd2+ 46. Kg1 Kg3 And all the check squares are covered.
moves.41... Rc3: The simple beauty of this move is that it prepares for Qe5+.  The computer thought this was slightly better than 41. ... Ra3 although I am not sure why.  It is possible that the rook on c3 could go to c4, and it also might control more squares the white queen could go to.
moves.42. Qf8+ Kg6 43. Qd6 h5:
This is about to be the last nail in the coffin.  Now if 44. h4 black's plan is 44. ... Kh7 followed by Rc1 followed by Qg1+ and and Rc3+.  If black plays 44. ... Rc1 immediately, then white can trade queens with Qg3+, which is still just as lost, but maybe takes longer.

So after 44. h4 Kh7 45. Qf4 Rc1 46. Rd3?! Qg1+ 47. Kg3 Rc4 48. Qf2 Rg4+ 49. Kf3 Rf4+
47... Kh7 is almost as good. 48. Qxf5+ Kg8 49. Qe6+ Kh8 50. Qe8+ Kh7 51. Qe3 (51. Qe5 h4 52. Qf5+ Kg8 53. Qe6+ Kh8 54. Qe8+ Kh7) 51... h4
